Alcohol Fuels Much of Crime By U.S. Troops in War Zones Alcohol is involved in a growing number of crimes by troops in to Iraq and Afghanistan. Alcohol- and drug-related charges were involved in more than a third of all Army criminal prosecutions of soldiers in the two war zones, according to records obtained by The New York Times through a Freedom of Information Act request. A1

Challenges For Bush in Mexico Protesters waited to meet President Bush on his visit to Mexico in a sign of the difficulty he faces as he tries to revive what many Mexicans see as a moribund partnership. A1

French Premier Endorses Rival Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin of France formally endorsed his political rival, the center-right candidate Nicolas Sarkozy, for president in a statement on Europe 1 radio. A6

U.S. Envoy Hopeful For Afghans The departing American ambassador to Afghanistan, Ronald E. Neumann, said that he did not see the Taliban as the threat it previously appeared to be, and that he was feeling ''reasonably optimistic'' about the state of the insurgency and the country's progress. A8

U.N. Council Condemns Sudan A United Nations Human Rights Council mission to Darfur said that the Sudanese government had organized and taken part in human rights crimes against its own population, and that international action to stop them had been inadequate. A12
NATIONAL A13-17

Republicans Find Division And Discontent With Party After years of political dominance, Republican voters now view their party as divided and say they are not satisfied with the choice of candidates seeking the Republican presidential nomination in 2008, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
A1

Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, said he would not enter the 2008 presidential race -- for the time being, at least -- so he could concentrate on domestic and global concerns, particularly helping secure an end to the Iraq war.

Army's Top Doctor Forced Out Lt. Gen. Kevin C. Kiley, the Army surgeon general has been forced into retirement, as the fallout continued from revelations of shoddy conditions for outpatients at the medical center.

College Cuts Ties With Sorority DePauw University severed ties with a national sorority that evicted two-thirds of the university's chapter members last year in what the sorority called an effort to improve its image for recruitment, but which the evicted women described as a purge of the unattractive or the uncool.

Guidelines for Food Handlers The Food and Drug Administration offered new, nonbinding guidelines to food packers to try to reduce the risk of food poisoning in fresh-cut produce but cannot say what caused the recent outbreaks connected to E. coli and salmonella.
NEW YORK/REGION B1-6

Crowd Jams Bronx Mosque To Mourn 10 Killed in Fire Hundreds of people packed into a Bronx mosque to say goodbye to 10 people who died in a fire last week. The dead included the wife and four children of Mamadou Soumare, whose bodies were flown back to Mali for burial, and the five children of Moussa Magassa, who were buried in a Muslim cemetery in New Jersey. A1
SCIENCE TIMES F1-8

Criticism for Gore's Film Al Gore's film on global warming, ''An Inconvenient Truth,'' won an Academy Award for best documentary, but part of his scientific audience is uneasy. In talks, articles and blog entries, those scientists argue that some of Mr. Gore's central points are exaggerated and erroneous.
F1
Health & Fitness F5
BUSINESS DAY C1-12

The Hedge Fund Lobby While hedge funds flex their muscles in the markets and in board rooms, in Washington they have experienced awkward growing pains. Now, united by a healthy sense of competition and a desire to avoid stringent regulation -- they have created three hedge fund lobbying groups.
